headline: CNN 10
subHeadline: Russia Announces National Day of Mourning Following Terror Attack at Moscow Concert Hall; Why E-Waste is a Growing Concern for the Environment; Two Astronauts Tell Us Their Experience While Working at the International Space Station; Disobedient Dog in a Swimming Pool Becomes Internet Star. Aired 4-4:10a ET

utterances.speaker: KIM BRUNHUBER, CNN INTERNATIONAL ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: These men in Ghana are rummaging through discarded electronics. Using screwdrivers and pliers, they breakdown computers and cell phones for any parts they can salvage. But this is just one electronic wasteland. An alarming new U.N. report says that since 2010, the amount of global e- waste has grown five times faster than it can be collected and recycled. According to the study, a record 62 million metric tons of e-waste was produced in 2022. That`s an increase of 82% from 2010. And the world is on track to generate a whopping 82 million tons of e-waste in 2030. What`s more, e-waste recycling only produces 1% of the rare earth elements needed to meet the current demand, which leaves the world highly dependent on just a few countries where rare earths are mined, including countries in Africa. The continent generates the lowest amount of e-waste, but recycling rates there are below 1%. A high-level official with the International Telecommunication Union says it`s up to the manufacturers to make a difference by giving devices a longer life cycle. While some countries have implemented environmental regulations to tackle the problem, some are working on a more grassroots level. Places like the Fixing Factory in London are teaching consumers to make more sustainable choices.

utterances.speaker: DERMOT JONES, PROJECT MANAGER, CAMDEN FIXING FACTORY
utterances.sentences: We buy these things, and the first time they fail, we don`t get them fixed. And we`re trying tochange that mindset. So when it fails, just think that`s just a part of its life cycle. It`s not the end of it. How can we get that going? How can you get it going a few more years? (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Ten second trivia. What is believed to be the most expensive object ever built?Shanghai Tower, International Space Station, Notre Dame Cathedral, Hong Kong International Airport. At a total cost of more than $100 billion, the ISS holds the record for most expensive object in history. We recently had the opportunity to speak with two astronauts who worked at the International Space Station, Dr. Peggy Whitson and John Shoffner. One of their main aims now is to inspire the next generation of astronauts. Mr. Shoffner started the International Space Art and Poetry Contest, and you can enter. Submit your space-themed art or poetry at spaceartcontest.com, and the lucky winners will see their masterpieces floating in space with astronauts. The submission deadline is April 5th, so get those wheels turning. We`d love nothing more than to share the story of a CNN 10 artist or poet gone galactic. Here`s part of our chat with Dr. Whitson and Mr. Shoffner. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: What is it like working in the International Space Station?

utterances.speaker: PEGGY WHITSON, ASTRONAUT, DIRECTOR OF HUMAN SPACE FLIGHT, AXIOM SPACE
utterances.sentences: It`s one of my favorite places. I love to go back all the time. It`s a reallycool laboratory and space. It`s such a privilege to be able to work there and conduct research there.

utterances.speaker: JOHN SHOFFNER, ASTRONAUT, PILOT, AXIOM SPACE
utterances.sentences: It`s a cool thing. It`s like working in an office building. You`ll pass someone in the hallway, and thenyou`ll go to where you`re working, and you just work. And then you`ll leave, and then you`ll pass somebody else going in. But everybody`s doing their thing. It was very comfortable.

utterances.speaker: WHITSON
utterances.sentences: And it`s really cool because you`re floating.

utterances.speaker: SHOFFNER
utterances.sentences: Will you fly over there and get me a battery? And say, OK, I`ll be right back.

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Peggy, do you think it`s important to inspire a next generation of astronauts?

utterances.speaker: WHITSON
utterances.sentences: I absolutely do. Both John and I were inspired by the Apollo-era astronauts. And I think what`s important about space now is it`s reallychanging dramatically. You know, with more and more commercial companies out there now, there`s just going to be so many avenues to get into space.

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: The International Space Art and Poetry Contest, what was the impetus for this?

utterances.speaker: SHOFFNER
utterances.sentences: In the Fourth Grade, I painted a picture of astronaut Ed White. He walked in space in that year, 1965. I just know there are other 10-year-olds out there today dreaming about space like I did. So let`s give them a chance. We should have this thing where they can draw something, and we`ll show it in space. So that was the beginning of it.

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Tell me about some of the parameters and some of the requirements for this contest.

utterances.speaker: SHOFFNER
utterances.sentences: We want original line art and/or poetry. And it`s about that question, what does it look like to live in space? So we have three studentcategories, 5 to 8, 9 to 13, and 14 to 18. Plus a teacher`s category. The other teachers can join in this year. Make it competitive. Go through the website, SpaceArtContest.com. All the rules are there and how to do it. It`s real simple. You just upload it. Everyone should just get in and let their imagination soar. It`s going to be beautiful. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Today`s story getting a 10 out of 10, a doggone undisciplined dog named Buster, who got busted for doing belly flops in the family pool againand again and again. The Florida family swears that he`s an otherwise obedient good boy, but this fur baby Buster just seems to have a serious weakness for pool time. Our Jeanne Moos has more. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) JENNIFER HENRY, BUSTER`S OWNER: Come here. JEANNE MOOS, CNN NATIONAL NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Buster has made a splash on the Internet.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Buster! Come here. Come here.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: With his lovable disobedience.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Come here. Come here.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: A Florida resident who can`t seem to leave the pool.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Be a good boy for once in your life.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: Buster is only a bad dog when it comes to the pool?

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: He`s not a rambunctious, crazy dog, except for whenever he wants to get in the pool.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: Jennifer Henry posted 10 feudal efforts.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Hey, are you ready to come in?

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: To get Buster out of the pool so she and her husband could make it to a dinner reservation.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Hey, this was my towel. Don`t you dare, Buster.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: But hey, at least he tends to bring the towel back out of the pool. It was only when her husband used his I mean business voice.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Let`s go, come on.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: That Buster and their 14-year-old dog Scooby headed for the house, though Buster contemplated taking one more dip.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No sir, Buster. Get over here now.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: You`ll notice both dogs disobey.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Come here. Come here.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: But only Buster gets busted.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: He`s the instigator. Scooby does not get in unless Buster gets in first.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: Jennifer has used a net to try and retrieve the retriever. When she`s really serious, she uses his full name. Buster. Buster Henry. Buster.(END VIDEOTAPE)
